janPolan-tutorial.message: Hello there! My name is Jan and yeah, I made this app. The purpose of it (besides me graduating) is to help you in getting your feet wet with process analysis and BPMN.
I think you're probably here because you enrolled in a course focused on process management. Am I right?

replies.message: Yeah, you nailed it.
Nope, but I wanted to educate myself at this topic and found this app.
Nah, I'm here by accident and I'm about to leave right now.

janPolan-tutorial.message: I knew it right from the moment I saw you!
Wow, that's really cool. I appreciate it!
Really? Don't you want to give it at least a shot?
Anyway, I'm going to tell you how this app works. Your goal will be to map a few process using the BPMN notation. Have you ever heard about it?

replies.message: Yes, I already know how the notation works and have experience using it.
I sort of know but I could use a refreshment.
What the hell are you talking about?

janPolan-tutorial.message: Allright, great!
No problem, you can find basic info about BPMN here for example: https://camunda.com/bpmn/. Read through them and then we can continue ;)
Using dialogues just like this one you will get informations about a process from several people, all of whom have a partial informations about it.
Your goal will be putting all of them together and draw the process using a drawing tool I imported from bpmn.io, so all credit for that goes to them.
What you see on your left is the conversation window. At the top of it is a chapter selection. Right now there is only the "Tutorial" option, because you havent unlocked any other chapters.
You can switch between different chapters using this selection.

Next important thig is the conversations window. If you've ever used Messenger you'll feel really familiar :) Basically by clicking on it you switch between the conversations and can go throught them.

replies.message: Thank you, Captain Obvious!
That looks easy enough.

janPolan-tutorial.message: You're welcome Lieutenant Sarcasm!
I hoped it would.
Anyway, once you go through all the conversations a new option will appear in the conversation options called "Draw the process"

When you click this you'll get the premade process with all activities, gateways, swimming lanes etc. in the bpmn.io tool. You job will be to connect them correctly together and put them into the correct lanes.
Whatever you do, do not try to add or remove any elements. If you add an element you will have to delete it but if you remove one, you will have to start over again.
If that happens or you'll get really lost in the drawing and decide to start over. There will be a Reset button in the toolbar. You can use that, I put it there for you.
If you were right you'll be able to unlock a new chapter, if you were not there will be a helpful advice there to help you out.

replies.message: Allright! I'm ready, let's get to it!
Thanks, so what now?

janPolan-tutorial.message: That's the spirit!
Now you'll try the tool!

Just try to connect the elements like this: 1 (starting event) - Activity 1 - 3 (exclusive gateway). From this gateway connect the Activity 2 and from here 5 (end). All of these will be in the swimming lane A.
Also from the exclusive gateway connect the Activity 3 to 7(end). These two belong into the B swimming lane.
I'll use my awesome super powers to summon the drawing window into the conversations window right now! Here we go!
PRESTO MAJESTO!
Bam! There we go!
Three more things I need to mention real quick. 1) If you refresh the webpage you loose all the progress and there is currently no way to save it
2) If you want to start a conversation again and pick different options, you can hit the Restart conversation button in the toolbar up top.
3) When you are at the drawing tool, go to another conversation and return back, the process drawn so far will be lost and you'll have to start over. Write the info down somewhere before you draw!
Allright, go for it, make me proud!

janPolan-chapterOne.message: Hello again! I'm glad to see you made it through the tutorial to the first chapter!
Now the real thing starts. Imagine a following scenario:
Your boss wants to see how your company hires new programmers and he wants YOU to make him a process schema.
He gives you a list of people who are involved in this process and now you are on your own.

charlieDoughnut.message: Oh, hello, are you the guy who is mapping the programmers hiring process?

replies.message: Yes, thats me!
No, I just came to disturb you.

charlieDoughnut.message: Then you succeded, now turn around and get out.
(He won't talk to you anymore, you should restart to conversation if you need information from him!)
Great, I was told you were coming. Look, I don't really have much time so I already prepared everything you might need to know.
Okay, my name is Charlie Doughnut. Don't laugh. I'm working as a backoffice HR support, so I handle all of the neccessary checks.

When the boss sends me the adepts for hiring I am the one who takes look at their history and status. First I do the background check, you know, if people don't lie about their diplomas, bad reputation etc.
Next I do the credit check. I know this is not a nice thing to do but we are dealing with a lot of data which someone desperate might want to steal.
Last thing I do is the reference check. I call all the contacts in the CV and see whether it was made up or not.
If everything looks good I give a "approved" rating into the system and thats it for me!

replies.message: Thanks, you've been super helpful!

charlieDoughnut.message: No problem, thats really all I can tell you, so if you wouldnt mind I need to get back to my work.

replies.message: Hello, Michael told me you could help me. Tell me please, what happens after you get the access rights request?
Hello, I'm mapping the rights access distribution process, could you help me?

martinTon.message: Hey, I have no idea what it is, but I'll try, I guess.

replies.message: Well I'm trying to describe how things are done around here.
Could you tell me what you do when the request for distributing the access rights reaches you?

martinTon.message: Sure, I check the database if the person already has a user. If he does not, I make one for him.
Then I grant him the rights.

replies.message: And if he already has a user?

martinTon.message: Oh, then I grant him the rights right away.

replies.message: Is that all?

martinTon.message: Yeah, the employee automatically receives and email and request is handled.

replies.message: Thanks a lot.

michaelHobitphile.message: Hey, I'm Michael. You must be the hero who will map our processes, right?

replies.message: Yes, that is exactly me. I've already been asked to map access rights distribution. Could you help me?

michaelHobitphile.message: Sure, when a developer needs some rights for access, he just fills out the form in our internal system.
There an automatic task is created for his manager, who either approves or denies the request.
If the request is denied, the whole process is over and the employee has to make the request again. This time the request should have more specific information about why it is needed.

replies.message: And if he approves?

michaelHobitphile.message: Another task is created for the system administrator. I don't really know what he does, you should ask him.

replies.message: Well thank you, you were most helpful.

lucasMullusc.message: Sup? Have you seen my energy drink somewhere around? I've been playing the new Mortal Kombat all night and am tottaly useless today.

replies.message: No, sorry. I'm mapping the request handling process and I need your help.
Really? I've heard it's really good. Let's play a game later but right now I need your help.

lucasMullusc.message: Hm, okay, what do you need from me.

replies.message: When you get a request from Ima, what do you do?

lucasMullusc.message: We check whether the problem is technical or not...

replies.message: What happens if it's not?

lucasMullusc.message: We send it back with our commentary to the client support to write why it's not.

replies.message: What happens when it is a technical problem?
And then?

lucasMullusc.message: Test center tests whether it's fixed or not.

replies.message: Is that all?

lucasMullusc.message: If it's not fixed they send it back. When we think it's fixed again we send it back.
This goes on until they are satisfied.
Sorry, I have stuff to do. Bye.
Deal! You came here to map what we do after Ima or her colleagues send us the alleged bugs, right?

replies.message: Exactly!

lucasMullusc.message: Well, first we analyze if it's really a bug. You know, sometimes the people dont't really know how to use the software correctly.
Then it depends. If it's not a bug we write a short commentary to Ima and she creates a response for the clients.
If we decide it's a bug hovewer, we have to solve it. After that it is up to the test center to test if the bug is fixed or not.

replies.message: Is that all you do?

lucasMullusc.message: Well, if it's not fixed we have to do it again. We iterate that with the test center until they are satisfied.

replies.message: Thanks, I'll catch up with you later for the game!
Hm
Hello, I'm mapping the client request handling process. I would need to know what happens when you are informed that the bug has been fixed.
Hello, I'm mapping the client request handling process. I would need to know what happens when you are informed that the bug has been fixed.
Thats it?
Would it kill you if you were a little more friendly?
What happends when the testing is done?

clutterbuck.message: I was friendly enough, considering you're wasting my time with things that I don't care about.

replies.message: Just help me with this and I'l be gone.
The director wants these processes mapped and you are obliged to assist me with that.
What happends when the testing is done?

clutterbuck.message: The bug is either fixed or not. If it's not we return it to the technical support. If it is okay we close the issue and maintenance takes care of the rest.

replies.message: So the process ends?
Well thank you.

ima.message: Hello, can I help you with something?

replies.message: Hello, I'm here to map the client handling process.
Hello, what can you tell me what you do when you receive a client request?

ima.message: Okay, what do you need to know?

replies.message: Can you tell me what it is that you do when you receive a client request?

ima.message: Sure, well first we take a look at the type of the request. If it's a technical problem, for example some kind of bug, we send it forward to the guys at the technical support. If it's something we can help with, we do so in a response and then we send it back!

replies.message: Is that all you do?

ima.message: Well, sometimes the technical support decides it is not something they should be bothered with and they give us a short explanation. It is up to us then to create the response again, you know, because the technical guy aren't really good at writing usually...

replies.message: Thanks a lot.
